newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Foreign workers in Israel fewer than believed.
newsitem.headline: Foreign workers in Israel fewer than believed.

text.p: The Central Bureau of Statistics on Monday published for the first time figures on foreign workers in Israel, indicating they number fewer than previously believed.
Foreign workers as of November 1995 totalled close to 110,000, including 61,000 with legal work permits and 47,000 illegal workers.
More recent figures for illegal workers were not available but the number of legal workers, as of August 1, 1996, had increased by 26,000 to 87,000.
Unofficial estimates had put the number of foreign workers at 250,000.
The government has begun considering ways to cut a growing dependence on foreign workers, who do low paying manual labour, particularly in construction and agriculture.
They have gradually been replacing Palestinians barred from the Jewish state for security reasons.
The statistics bureau's data is based on the Interior Ministry's border-crossing figures and information from the National Insurance Institute.
Among the legal workers, more than 70 percent are from Romania and Thailand. STR TCC
